tossups.question: According to contemporary accounts, an early ruler of this country threw two columns off of his ship and settled where they landed. Previously, it had been inhabited by Irish monks called Papar. Later, this country was absorbed by another in the Old Covenant, which was signed after a long war called the Sturlung Era and left it under Norwegian rule. The oldest parliament in the  world is this country’s Althing. For 10 points, name this small volcanic country in the North Atlantic Ocean.

In 1861 John C. Fremont was criticized for putting this state under martial law. One Senator  from this state was nicknamed “Old Bullion” for his opposition to paper money; that was Thomas Hart Benton. Dr. John Emerson purchased Dred Scott in this state. This state’s city of Independence was the start of the Oregon Trail. For the point, name this border state admitted under the Compromise of 1820.

An alliance between these two countries came about after the failure to renew the  Reinsurance Treaty in 1890. The alliance between these two countries was meant to force the Triple Alliance to fight a war on two fronts. One war plan to defeat these two countries involved sweeping through Belgium and was named for von Schlieffen. For the point, name these two great powers that presented threats on either side of Imperial Germany.
tossups.answer: Russian Empire and the France [or Imperial Russia and the French Third Republic; or RossiyskayaImperiyaand La Troisieme Republique francaise] [Patrick Liao]

tossups.question: One empire based in this modern day nation built its capital at Lalibela and was led by the Agaw people. A kingdom in this nation had a port at Adulis and spoke the Ge’ez language, in which the Kebra Negast was written. Under Ezana, that kingdom in this nation converted to Christianity and its rulers were supposedly of the Solomonic Line. For the point, name this nation ruled by the Zagwe and Axumite Kingdoms, a landlocked country in the Horn of Africa.

While serving in this organization, Jon Burge tortured hundreds of African-American men. This organization arrested a British Member of Parliament while breaking up a protest that ended in the arrest of Abbie Hoffman and his six accomplices. In February 2015, this organization was  found to be operating a “Black House” where suspects were held without outside contact, embarrassing Mayor Rahm Emanuel. For the point, name this law enforcement group of Illinois’ largest city.
tossups.answer: Chicago Police Department [or Chicago P.D.; prompt on CPD] [Bruce Arthur]

tossups.question: A leader of this last name declared her intention to dissolve her country’s Secretariat of Intelligence in January 2015. An arrest warrant for that politician of this last name was found in the trash of prosecutor Alberto Nisman. Another politician with this last name cleared the way for prosecution of officials who committed abuses in his country’s “Dirty War”. For the point, give this last name of the Argentine Prime Ministers Cristina and Néstor.
tossups.answer: Kirchner [accept Cristina Fernández de Kirchner; accept Néstor Kirchner; accept Fernandez before “Dirty War”] [Ryan Rosenberg]

tossups.question: This man, who served as an “anti-poverty czar” in the Nixon administration, once  differentiated between “known knowns”, “known unknowns”, and “unknown unknowns.” This man’s namesake “doctrine” emphasizes high-tech weapons and air strikes rather than more ground forces, and was coined by reporters to describe his strategy during the Iraq War. For the point, name this man who also served as Secretary of Defense from 2001-2006 under George W. Bush.

One person of this first name enlisted Jean Fernel to help her husband’s sexual problems and  orchestrated the St. Bartholomew’s Day Massacre as regent to Charles IX. A ruler with this first name issued the “Toleration of All Faiths Edict.” That ruler of this name faced a revolt led by a false Peter III and presided over the second and third partitions of Poland. For the point, give this  female name common to a French queen from the Medici and a “great” empress of Russia.

The “percentages agreement” was established at this meeting. The accords from this meeting called for the expansion of a government based in Lublin. Part of Sakhalin and the Kuril Islands were given to one participant in this meeting, and that participant agreed to attack the Japanese empire 90 days after Germany was defeated. For the point, name this conference between the  “Big Three” Allied leaders in the Crimea near the end of World War II.

The written works that prompted this meeting include Address to the Christian Nobility and The Babylonian Captivity of the Church. This meeting occurred in response to the papal bull Exsurge Domine. This meeting was presided over by the Emperor Charles V, who later banned the possession of early Protestant texts. For the point, name this imperial diet of the Holy Roman Empire where Martin Luther defended his ideas from charges of heresy.

This war included the Battle of El Caney, where the winning side was led by Henry Lawton. Another battle fought during this war included a heroic charge up San Juan Hill. Some have alleged that this war was encouraged by the Yellow Journalism of Joseph Pulitzer and William Randolph Hearst. One cause of this war was possibly accidental explosion of the USS Maine in Havana harbor. For the point, name this war which led to US control of Guam, the Philippines, and Cuba.

In this city, Jerzy Kulczycki opened The Blue Bottle after recovering sacks of a certain food item from retreating Turks. A group of philosophers from this city promulgated the ideas of Ernst Mach and advocated logical positivism. The arrival of the Nazis caused the decline of the “coffee-house culture” in this city, which was also where a thinker wrote The Interpretation of Dreams and The Ego and the Id. For the point, name this workplace of Sigmund Freud, the capital city of Austria.

Toussaint Dubreil represented this group as a hydra being crushed beneath the feet of the king. During the War of the Three Henrys, a Dominican monk linked with this group  assassinated Henry III, ending the Valois Dynasty. During the Day of the Barricades, Henry of Guise led this group in taking over Paris. For the point, name this organization that opposed the accession of Henry of Navarre and sought to eradicate the Huguenots during the French Wars of Religion.

This politician initiated a controversial National Energy Program and included a  Notwithstanding Clause in the Charter of Rights and Freedoms when he repatriated his country’s constitution. This predecessor of John Turner said “Just Watch Me” during the October Crisis and was in power during the first Quebec independence referendum. For the point, name this Liberal politician who was Prime Minister of Canada for most of the 1970s.
tossups.answer: Joseph Philippe Pierre Yves Elliott Trudeau [or Trudeau Sr.] [Patrick Liao]

tossups.question: This city was the site of a deadly 1811 theater fire that was once thought to have killed Edgar Allen Poe’s parents. An 1863 bread riot occurred in this site of the first electric trolley system in the US. It was the site of Tredegar Iron Works, a major wartime manufacturing plant.  This city was the target of McClellan’s Peninsula Campaign, and many of its officials fled to Danville after it fell in 1865. For the point, name this Southern city which replaced Montgomery as capital of the Confederacy.

In the aftermath of this event, a still on-going refugee problem studied by Benny Morris occurred which is part of the greater “Nakba.” This event followed the heels of the passage of UN resolution 181. This event was solidified in a speech dated 5th of Iyar 5708 which noted the “natural right” of a people to be “masters of their own fate,” and was given by David Ben-Gurion  at an event that had the singing of “Hatikva.” For the point, identify this 1948 event that formalized a nation that included Tel Aviv.
tossups.answer: The founding of the State of Israel [accept equivalents for “founding,” as well as “Israeli independence” and similar answers reflecting clear knowledge] [Dan Passner]

tossups.question: Children in this city state were ritually whipped during a contest to steal cheese from Artemis’ temple. The Eurypontid and Agiad dynasties ruled this city-state, which was partially governed by a legislative body of 30 elder men called the gerousia. Xerxes I won a battle over a force containing 300 hoplites from this city-state at a narrow pass in 480 BCE.For the point, name this city-state led by Leonidas at the Battle of Thermopylae.

A minor character in this series is referred to as “Five” because his father changed his family’s names to numbers. This series’ main character idolizes the baseball player Joe Shlabotnik, while another character in this series refers to another as her “sweet baboo.” Rerun  was introduced later in this series’ run, and its other characters include Sally, Schroeder, and Lucy van Pelt. For the point, name this comic strip that featured the hapless Charlie Brown, a creation of Charles Schulz.

The McDonald Ranch House was a key assembly site for this program. A “Special Engineer Detachment” who worked on it operated IBM punch-card calculators under the supervision of Hans Bethe and Richard Feynman. Dropping pieces of paper helped Enrico Fermi calculate the yield of one of its prototypes. For the point, name this progam supervised by general Leslie Grove and directed by J. Robert Oppenheimer, which resulted in the first atomic bomb.
tossups.answer: The Manhattan Project [prompt on “making the atomic bomb” or similar answers before mention] [Dennis Loo]

tossups.question: A composer from this modern country wrote the opera Manru and a world-famous Minuet in G before becoming its prime minister. The composer of Threnody to the Victims of Hiroshima is from this country. Another composer fled this country shortly before the November Uprising, which inspired his Revolutionary Etude. The mazurka is a folk dance from this birthplace of the composer of the Minute Waltz. For the point, name this European country, the home of Ignacy Paderewski, Krzysztof Penderecki, and Frederic Chopin.
tossups.answer: Poland [or the Republic of Poland; or Rzeczpospolita Polska] [Rob Carson]

tossups.question: A foreign minister of this country, Edvard Kardelj, was the main architect of its “socialist self-management” policy. The Non-Aligned Movement was founded in its capital. In 1948, this communist country split ideologically from the Soviet Union. It was first led by the former partisan Josip Broz Tito, and its constituent republics included Croatia and Serbia. For the point, name this Balkan nation that broke up in 1991.
tossups.answer: Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia [or Socijalisticka Federativna Republika Jugoslavija] [Saul Hankin]

tossups.question: This coach recruited the first African-American scholarship player in the ACC, Charlie Scott. He pioneered the use of per-possession statistics in college basketball and created a unique offense designed around isolation guard play. This proponent of the “Four Corners” offense mentored Roy Williams and coached Phil Ford and Michael Jordan. For the point, name this former coach of, and namesake of the arena now used by, the North Carolina men’s basketball team.

This kingdom was badly defeated at the Battle of Blood River by a force led by Andries Pretorius, but it crushed a force led by Lord Chelmsford at the Battle of Isandlwana. The last leader of this kingdom was captured after the fall of Ulundi, this kingdom’s capital. Mpande and Cetshwayo (ketsh-WHY-oh) were rulers of this kingdom, whose military was renowned for using the assegai. For the point, name this kingdom founded by Shaka in present-day South Africa.

Recent cases such as Vann v. Salazar involve this tribe’s dealings with its namesake freedmen, and this tribe formed the Phoenix newspaper. John Ross served as principal chief of this tribe as it contested Worcester v. Georgia, and Sequoyah invented a syllabary alphabet for these people. The Treaty of New Echota led to their relocation from Georgia under the Indian Removal Act of 1830. For the point, name this tribe forcibly removed by Winfield Scott in the Trail of Tears.

The first word in this title means “ocean,” signifying great knowledge. The “Great Fifth” of these figures constructed their Potala palace. Those who hold this office are considered a yang srid, or reincarnation, of its first holder, Dge-’dun-grub-pa. The 14th and current holder of this office, Tenzin Gyatso, fled to India in 1959 after his homeland revolted against communist China. For the point, name this leader of “Yellow Hat” Tibetan Buddhists.

Agabus the Decapolitan narrates a novel about this man by Robert Graves whose title declares him a “King”. This man is taught the ways of hedonism by a shepherd and learns of his prodigious fishing talent in a 1991 novel. He hallucinates a long dream sequence in which he has a large family in a novel adapted into a 1988 Martin Scorsese film. Jose Saramago and Nikos Kazantzakis, respectively, wrote about The Gospel According to and The Last Temptation of this man. For the point, name this religious leader from Nazareth.
tossups.answer: JesusChrist [accept either underlined answer; acceptKing Jesus] [Rob Carson]
